awd_titl_txt: International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: May 7-10, 2019 in Dayton, Ohio
awd_abstract_narration:
The 20th International Symposium on Aviation Psychology (ISAP) will be held May 7-10, 2019 in Dayton, Ohio. ISAP is a forum to present the latest research on human performance problems and opportunities within aviation, envision design solutions that best use human capabilities in safe and efficient aviation systems, and bring together scientists and operators to bridge the gap between research and application.  The symposium encourages researchers to focus basic research on applied needs. The knowledge generated would not be limited to aviation applications. For example, principles of perceptual representations that could guide cockpit display designs should also apply to displays for spaceships, automobiles, nuclear power plants, and other interactive control displays.

The symposium covers basic research issues on cognition, perception, and neuroscience. These topics are studied in the context of cognitive systems, human-system integration, display and visualization, training and simulation, automated and autonomous systems, personnel selection, and sociotechnical system effectiveness, as applied to aviation systems on the ground, in the sky, and in space. One common approach to reduce the often significant time lag between discovery and application is to allow practical needs to inform basic research priorities. In contrast, the philosophy of ISAP is that meaningful dialogues between researchers and practitioners are key to advancing knowledge and putting knowledge to practical use. In two companion ISAP plenary panel sessions, practitioners (e.g., pilots, air traffic controllers, maintenance personnel) present the critical safety issues that they face and researchers present the latest scientific and technological approaches to achieving solutions. These sessions are in addition to three invited plenary speakers purposely selected from different scientific disciplines and pertinent aviation domains. Over the course of the symposium, researchers will have the opportunity to present their latest scientific, engineering, or methodological work in either a spoken or a poster session. ISAP also places a special emphasis on fostering student involvement by conducting a Best Student Paper Competition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 20th International Symposium on Aviation Psychology (ISAP) was held May 7-10, 2019 in Dayton, Ohio. The prime directive of the ISAP biennial series is to promote basic psychological research and engineering solutions for a more efficient and safer sky. The symposium is offered for the purposes of: (a) presenting the latest research on human performance problems and opportunities within aviation; (b) envisioning design solutions that best utilize human capabilities in safe and efficient aviation systems; and (c) bringing together scientists and operators to bridge the gap between research and application. The need is driven by both unprecedented technological advances and an anticipated explosive increase in air transportation. The symposium provides a forum for researchers to focus basic research on applied needs with a principled approach. The knowledge generated would not be limited to aviation applications. The safety and efficiency benefits of principled solutions will generalize to domains beyond aviation. For example, principles of perceptual representations that could guide cockpit display designs should also apply to displays for spaceships, automobiles, nuclear power plants, medical equipment, and so forth. 

The 20th symposium covered basic research issues on cognition, perception, and neuroscience. These topics were studied in the context of cognitive systems, human-system integration, display and visualization, training and simulation, automated and autonomous systems, personnel selection, and sociotechnical system effectiveness as applied to the many aspects of the aviation system that spans the ground, sky, and space. In all, 111 spoken presentations and 50 posters were presented. The spoken session topics included multisensory interactions, designing for display support, human-machine teaming, pilot and air traffic controller training, and aviation selection. In addition, three workshops were offered: 1. Neuroergonomics in Aviation: Translating Human Performance Assessment from Lab to Operational Environment,  2. Applied Cognitive Systems Engineering in Air Traffic Control, and 3. Using Patterns Characterizing Group Differences to Solve Data Analysis Problems. 

With constant and rapid technological advances, a successful approach to maximize human capital is not to react to each technological development but to develop scientific principles that consider human strengths and limits. One way to reduce the often, significant time lag between scientific discovery and application is to allow practical needs to inform basic research priorities. It is the foundational philosophy of ISAP that meaningful dialogues between researchers and practitioners are key to advancing knowledge and putting knowledge to practical use. In two companion ISAP plenary panel sessions, practitioners (pilots, safety and regulatory program manager, unmanned aerial system administrator, accident investigator) presented the critical safety issues that they faced and researchers (psychologists and engineers) presented the latest scientific and technological promising approaches to help with the pressing issues in the aviation system. 

Three plenary addresses reflect the multidisciplinary nature of the symposium. Chairman Robert Sumwalt, National Transportation Safety Board, delivered the keynote address on Aviation Human Factors: Lessons Learned From the Sifting Through the Ashes; Dr. Charles Spence, Oxford University, presented the invited address on Neuroscience-Inspired Multisensory Design, and Dr. Amy Pritchett, Pennsylvania State University, presented the invited address, Re-Architecting the Human-Autonomy Team. 

To underscore the importance of investment in training young investigators for the field, the symposium has the tradition of encouraging student participation by deeply discounting student registration fees. Approximately 30% of the 20th ISAP participants were students who came from nine countries. To promote excellence, a featured event of the Symposium is the Best Student Paper Competition. The 20th ISAP received 19 entries and the five finalists came from three countries. 

Eighty-three papers were published in the Proceedings of the 20th International Symposium on Aviation Psychology. The 20th ISAP Proceedings has worldwide access through the Delft University of Technology Research Repository,  https://doi.org/10.4233/uuid:c8e9b17b-89ea-4faf-b55c-767c1ae070ef as well as through the Wright State University institutional digital depository, Core Scholar, https://corescholar.libraries.wright.edu/isap_2019/

Altogether, the symposium had 288 attendees from 23 countries. Approximately 20% of the participants were international participants. Reflecting the interdisciplinary nature of the symposium, participants were a mix of researchers, operational personnel, and administrators from academia (52%), government (25%), and industry (23%). Researchers and students attending the symposium came from diverse fields that include aviation, psychology, neuroscience, engineering, computer science, and aerospace medicine.
